questions.text: Identify the pathogen having the following cell structure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspergillus Given image is Fungus cell wall In Aspergillus, the predominant cell wall components are polysaccharides synthesized by transmembrane synthases, transglycosidases and glycosyl hydrolases . The main core of A. fumigatus cell wall consists of a polymer of β-1,3-glucan and chitin which is responsible for the rigidity of this structure. Chitin: Chitin constitutes a much bigger fraction of the cell wall in filamentous fungi than in yeast, around 10–20% of the dry weight of cell walls. Polymers consisting mainly of unbranched chains of β-(1, 4) - linked-N-Acetylglucosamine in the Ascomycota and Basidiomycota, or poly- β- (1, 4)- linked-N-Acetylglucosamine (Chitosan) in the Zygomycota. Both chitin and chitosan are synthesized and extruded at the plasma membrane Glucans: The other major cell wall component in fumigatus is β-1,3-glucan which is synthesized by a glucan synthase complex which contains two subunits, using UDP-glucose as a substrate. glucose polymers that function to cross-link chitin or chitosan polymers, β-glucans are glucose molecules linked via β- (1, 3) - or β- (1, 6) -bonds and provide rigidity to the cell wall while α-glucans are defied by α -(1, 3) and function as part of the matrix. The catalytic subunit is encoded by FKS1 gene, the target of echinocandins drugs. This gene is unique but non-essential in fumigatus . Proteins: Enzymes necessary for cell wall synthesis and lysis in addition to structural proteins are all present in the cell wall. Most of the structural proteins found in the cell wall are glycosylated and contain mannose, thus these proteins are called mannoproteins or mannans. Option B - Mycoplasma - Mycoplasma is a genus of bacteria that, like the other members of the class Mollicutes, lack a cell wall around their cell membranes. Peptidoglycan is absent. This characteristic makes them naturally resistant to antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis. They can be parasitic or saprotrophic. Option C - Mycobacterium - Mycobacteria are surrounded by a double membrane cell envelope that is exceedingly rich in lipids. No less than 60% of the mycobacterial cell envelope is estimated to be lipids as compared to 20% in the cell envelope of Gram-negative organisms Option D - Rhinosporidium - Rhinosporidium seeberi is a eukaryotic pathogen responsible for rhinosporidiosis, a disease which affects humans, horses, dogs, and to a lesser extent cattle, cats, foxes, and birds. It is most commonly found in tropical areas, especially India and Sri Lanka.

Solution:

Sclerotic Body Given images show sclerotic or medlar or copper penny bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis. It is typically seen with a history of warty lesion after wood prick. Chromoblastomycosis is also known as dematiaceous fungus or pigmented fungal disease because of these medlar bodies having a muriform cell appearance/ copper penny appearance. It is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by several different dematiaceous fungi and resulting in the formation of slow-growing warty plaques and cauliflower-like lesions which may ulcerate. The fungi produce thick-walled, single or multicellular clusters called sclerotic or muriform bodies, respectively. The fungi are usually introduced into the body by trauma, and the lesions are mostly found on exposed regions of the body. In the dermis, a granuloma composed of epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells is visible. The fungal elements are visible as sclerotic bodies, which are brown septate cells. The sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies/ muriform bodies/copper pennies) are extruded transepidermally, and they appear as black dots on the surface of the lesion; this is characteristic of chromoblastomycosis The surface is scraped, and 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to the scrapings, which the examiner then viewed under the microscope. The disease runs a chronic course and most cases can be cured.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - capsulated yeast - e.g. cryptococcus Cryptococcus is a genus of fungi in the family Cryptococcaceae that includes both yeasts and filamentous species. The filamentous, sexual forms or teleomorphs were formerly classified in the genus Filobasidiella, while Cryptococcus was reserved for the yeasts Option B - non capsulated yeast are rare in occurrence. Option D - none is not the correct option. Sclerotic bodies - T he term chromoblastomycosis is restricted to the cases in which sclerotic cells are present in tissue . Sclerotic cells, also known as Medlar bodies, are globe-shaped, cigar-colored, thick-walled structures that are 4-12 µm in diameter

questions.text: False about rabies vaccination: Deltoid is the preferred location Dose of equine Ig is 20 IU/Kg Equine lg can be used (if Human IG is not present) Not given after 72 hours Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4 only Explanation for incorrect options:- Option D - Vaccine can be given upto days provides protection until active immunity begins [7-10 days since initiation of vaccination) Human rabies immunoglobulin should be administered via the intramuscular route If a large volume (> 2 ml for children or > 5 ml for adults) is required, it is recommended to administer this in divided doses at different sites. The immunoglobulin and the vaccine should be administered at two different sites of the body. The wound should be cleaned with soap and disinfectant Injections of the immunoglobulin should preferably be administered over the bitten site The Ig material should be carefully infiltrated in the depth of and around the wound. Any remainder should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from that used for the rabies vaccine. If intramuscular administration is contraindicated (bleeding disorders), the injection can be administered subcutaneously.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - In cases of very young or small children: Usually given over deltoid Given in all Class III bites Not used after 7 days of bite or injury Either it should be given in 24 hours Leftover should be given IM on opposite site of gluteus muscles Option B – HRIG ( Human Rabies Immunoglobulin ): 20 IU/kg (should be infiltrated as much as possible around the wound) Option C – ERIG ( Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin ): 40 IU/kg Hyper sensitivity test should be done before use (more allergic compared to HRIg) Guide to post-exposure prophylaxis following risk assessment Post-exposure prophylaxis* Rabies exposure risk Unimmunised / incompletely immunised individual** Fully immunised individual No risk None None Low risk Five doses (each 1ml ampoule of 2.5 IU) rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 30 Two doses (each 1ml ampoule of 2.5 IU) rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3-7 High risk Five doses (each 1ml ampoule of 2.5 IU) rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 30, plus HRIG (within 7 days of starting the course of vaccine) Two doses (each 1ml ampoule of 2.5 IU) rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3-7 * Post-exposure rabies vaccine should be given via the intramuscular route (or by deep subcutaneous injection for people with bleeding disorders). If an individual arrives in the UK having started post-exposure prophylaxis via the intradermal route, they should receive the remaining doses via the intramuscular route. Where a regime has been started that is different to that used in the UK, specialist advice should be sought. * Persons who have not received a full course of pre- or post-exposure tissue culture rabies vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following belongs to the class Mollicutes ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ureaplasma Urealyticum Mycoplasmas belong to class Mollicutes, order Mucoplasmatales. These are bacteria that lack a cell wall , one of the principal cellular and morphological structures of most prokaryotes. These wall-less organisms, earlier called either “pleuropneumonia-like organisms” or “mycoplasmas”, are also the smallest free-living, self-replicating forms currently known. It is important to note that bacteria are organisms that occur as single cells and have a cell wall made up of peptidoglycan molecules; while mollicutes are single-celled organisms that have no cell wall and have only a simple genome. The term mycoplasmas and class Mollicutes, are often used interchangeably. The most common is Ureaplasma urealyticum 2 nd most - M. Genitalium & M. Hominis associated with common non Gonococcal urethritis 3 rd most common is C. trachomatis associated with Reiter's syndrome

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Classification of rickettsiae Kingdom Bacteria Phylum Proteobacteria Class Alphaproteobacteria Order Rickettsiales Family Rickettsiacege Genus Rickettsia Option C - Because of their dependence on host biosynthetic machinery, the chlamydiae were originally thought to be viruses; however, they have a cell wall and contain DNA, RNA, and ribosomes and therefore are now classified as bacteria. The group consists of a single genus, Chlamydia (order Chlamydiales, class Chlamydiaceae). Option D - Streptococcus is a diverse genus and its classification has changed several times. Streptococci are firmicutes of the order Lactobacillus’s and belong to family Streptococcaceae.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid fast organism? Nocardia Actinomycetes leprae Isospora Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3,4 Acid fast stain are differential stains its different between acid fast & nonacid fast is the ability to resist decolorization by acids during staining procedures. It is due to presence of mycolic acid More the mycolic acid more will be acid fastness This means that once the bacterium is stained, it cannot be decolorized using acids routinely used in the process. This important and unique feature of certain bacteria gives the ability to classify and detect them using relatively easy laboratory procedures such as microscopy. Bacteria displaying acid fastness include: Genus Mycobacterium – M. leprae, M. tuberculosis, M. smegmatis, M. Avium complex, M. kansasii. Genus Nocardia – N. brasiliensis, N. Cyriac Georgica, N. farcinica, and N. nova. Acid fastness can also be attributed to other structures not classified as bacteria. These include: Bacterial endospores Head of sperm Cryptosporidium parvum Isospora belli Cyclospora cayetanensis Taenia saginata eggs Hydatid cysts Sarcocystis Nuclear inclusion bodies in lead poisoning Option A -1% acid fast Option B - Some of these species are acid fast organisms Option C - 5% acid fast Option D - 0.5 to 1% acid fast These species are coccidian parasites which cause diarrhea in HIV+ ve individuals comments one is cryptosporidium & cyclospora

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Plasmodium falciparum?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperglycemia Plasmodium falciparum causes hypoglycemia, and not hyperglycemia. The most characteristic symptom of malaria is fever. Other common symptoms include chills, headache, myalgias, nausea, and vomiting. Diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cough are occasionally seen. As the disease progresses, some patients may develop the classic malaria paroxysm with bouts of illness alternating with symptom-free periods In all types of malaria the periodic febrile response is caused by rupture of mature schizonts. In P vivax and P ovale malaria, a brood of schizonts matures every 48 hr, so the periodicity of fever is tertian (“tertian malaria”), whereas in P malariae disease, fever occurs every 72 hours (“quartan malaria”). The fever in falciparum malaria may occur every 48 hr, but is usually irregular, showing no distinct periodicity. Splenomegaly is common but may not be apparent early in disease. Hepatomegaly, jaundice, hypotension and abdominal tenderness may also be seen. Malaria does not cause lymphadenopathy and is not associated with a rash. A variety of laboratory abnormalities may be seen in a case of uncomplicated malaria. These include normochromic, normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis or leukopenia, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, elevated liver and renal function tests, proteinuria, and laboratory evidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (although clinically important bleeding is rare). Eosinophilia is not seen. Patients with complicated malaria occasionally show evidence of massive intravascular hemolysis with hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Malaria may result in not having enough red blood cells for an adequate supply of oxygen to your body's tissues (anemia). Low blood sugar. Severe forms of malaria can cause low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), as can quinine — a common medication used to combat malaria. Very low blood sugar can result in coma or death. Option B - Kidney involvement by P. falciparum. AKI is a known complication of malaria and can occur in around 40% of patients with severe disease by P. falciparum in endemic regions, contributing to high mortality rate, around 75% of cases Option C - Hypoglycemia is a frequently encountered complication in falciparum malaria that is usually ascribed to increased glucose use and impaired glucose production caused by the inhibition of gluconeogenesis.

On the inner membrane are two poles Infective Form: Eggs Life cycle: Eggs are ingested with contaminated food & water → Eggs hatch in intestine 🡪 Cysticercoid larvae released → Attach to the intestinal layers → Changes to Adult from → Produce eggs → Eggs passed out In Feces Sometimes Eggs hatch within intestine and releases hexacanth embryo which penetrates the intestinal walls and gets back into circulation leads to auto infection (Option A) - Most patients are asymptomatic. Patients with heavy burden of pathogens may present with nausea, ABD pain, generalized itchiness, anorexia, diarrhea, etc. Egg Contains polar filaments and in between central hooklets

questions.text: Identify the life cycle of the following parasite ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Strongyloides Stercoralis Given image is the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis . Distinctive features include ( a ) random migration of auto infective larvae, ( b ) embryonated egg rapidly hatches to rhabditiform larvae, and ( c ) single generation of free-living male and female adults. This helminth is set apart from others that commonly affect humans by (a) the internal autoinfection cycle with auto infective larvae randomly migrating through tissue, parthenogenesis, and the potential for lifelong infection in the host, the profound pathology occurring in hyperinfection and systemic manifestations of strongyloidiasis, and (b) a limited external cycle with a single generation of free-living adults.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - H nana life cycle - Option B - N. americanus life cycle - Option C - Ancylostoma duodenale -

questions.text: Which is correct about Anti CMV lgG antibody?

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic CMV infection, patient is immune to other strains of CMV in future

options.label: C
options.text: History of CMV infection and now in latency

options.label: D
options.text: IgG avidity assay help in distinguishing primary infection from past infection

questions.correct_answer: D. IgG avidity assay help in distinguishing primary infection from past infection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IgG avidity assay help in distinguishing primary infection from past infection A positive test for CMV IgG indicates that a person was infected with CMV at some time during their life but does not indicate when a person was infected. This applies for persons ≥12 months of age when maternal antibodies are no longer present. IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents. These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. (Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation. However, in infants <3 months of age, transplacentally derived maternal IgG antibodies with high avidity index influenced IgG avidity result of the children. IgG antibodies are mostly maternally transferred antibodies, while the demonstration of IgM antibodies in the newborn is indicative of congenital infection, because maternal IgM antibodies can’t be transplacentally acquired.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Denotes only past CMV infection - this is not correct as it don’t confirm about recent or past infection. A high level of IgG is not as important as a rising level. If there is a 4-fold increase in IgG between the first and second sample, then you have an active CMV infection (primary or reactivated). A positive CMV IgM and negative IgG means you may have very recently been infected. Option B - Chronic CMV infection, patient Is immune to other strains of CMV in future - this is completely wrong statement as the strains don’t provide immunity to each other, The 11 species in this genus include human beta herpesvirus 5 (HCMV, human cytomegalovirus, HHV-5), which is the species that infects humans. Diseases associated with HHV-5 include mononucleosis and pneumonia. In the medical literature, most mentions of CMV without further specification refer implicitly to human CMV. Option C - not necessary to be in latency - chronic cases and cases with reminiscence may also present with positive IgG anti cmv.
